Spectrum who were high uh were more focused on um end user needs uh they
found that they were running into a lot of issues where they had to learn a lot about kubernetes just to be productive
with like operating their service so we wanted to think about how we could reduce this uh and one of the answers
that we for this was backstage uh so if you haven't heard of
Backstage uh it is a platform for building developer portals that was created at Spotify so engineers at
Spotify use backstage every day uh it's our kind of one place to go to to run
operations tasks and uh and ccii view documentation monitor your
kubernetes deployment uh and if you watch the talk yesterday on Hendrick you'll also see
that the place to go to uh for machine learning Engineers to uh to track their models and see their usage so we've made
it the real one place to go to manage all of your services and it doesn't matter what your service is whether it's
front end backend client uh ml
data one of the the critical like important features to Backstage is the
software catalog and before we had the software catalog in backstage we had an
Excel sheet and there's a really great talk by Patrick oldsberg about how we change from using an Excel sheet to a
software catalog and maybe that Excel sheet sounds familiar and it usually it has who owns this service where's the
get repo what is its relationship to other service but it can also have a lot of other things because the very
interesting thing about the software catalog is that it's customizable and extensible so you can create plugins for
the software catalog that operate within the context of the service you're looking at which is very important
because if we want to answer that question we talked about earlier where is my service we don't want the user to
have to remember which cluster it is and which name space it is we just want them to see
it so for example you go into backstage this is the open source backstage with
my test app dice roller that rolls dice um you click dice roller and you can see
lots of different tabs there cicd API docs and then the kubernetes tab so
click the kubernetes tab and it just gives you the information you don't have to go hunting for it it doesn't matter how many clusters you have you're just
given it uh which is fantastic and it it was a bit of a lifesaver for us uh
having thousands of services and dozens of clusters so like I said backstage
becomes the one interface to your service and this software catalog is critical to that and we're going to talk
about why now uh because what we've done is we've changed the interaction our
user or has with their own services so instead of thinking I want to look at service a let me just switch into
infrastructure mode and think about the Clusters where it is so I can set up the context correctly or go to the right
kubernetes dashboard uh or the right name space they just go to Backstage and they go straight there uh this reduces a
lot of toil even though it's quite a simple thing that we were able to do but what we've done is uh is quite
interesting because you're changing the user's interaction with the infrastructure so now they're completely
Focus fed on their service the entire way through the process they go to Backstage thinking about service a could
be anything could be playlist API um and they go to kubernetes and they see all the playlist a API resources straight
away without having to think about the cluster it's on the name space or where it's deployed and this is something that's
really important to do because you want to prevent context switching uh which hurts
productivity so the other question we wanted to answer which is a bit of an earlier one
is uh is the service healthy uh because this is a a question that we we get a
lot from Engineers like I said we have that spectrum of Engineers uh Engineers who
are very confident with kubernetes and Engineers who are more hyperfocused on features so we got a lot of support
questions which reduces productivity uh support questions are great and we should always Provide support but they
are opport unities to get better at what we do uh so every time you get a support
question there's a QE time between when the user asks it uh and when we can respond I'm based in New York a lot of
our Engineers are based in Stockholm so that's quite a q time sometimes uh and then we have to look into the uh the
issue and then we get back to them with with uh like a resolution uh so this is like a big productivity killer and my
colleague Richard Tolman and I uh were thinking about uh what we were going to do do at hack Day last year and we
thought okay what if we could like self-service a lot of these support questions and and answers to our users
so that they didn't have to come to us uh they could just like figure it out themselves and make it easy for them to
figure it out and a common question we got was my deployment has failed and I
don't know why uh this I'm getting this error message it says progress deadline exceeded and I and honestly I just want
to get my feature right there we thought fair enough you know we don't want the infrastructure to actually get in the
way of their job we want the opposite um so like I said we thought about okay how can we make this easier to
debug and starting from what we had uh this is a view of the uh the open source
pod table in backstage uh one of the problems with it is that it's actually kind of difficult to scan for errors uh

and the problem is it doesn't really give you a holistic view of of of your service and scanning through a table isn't quite quite as quick as like an
instant visualization that tells you yes or no it's good or it's not good so we wanted something a lot more Visual and
like I said something that could tell you straight away if something wasn't right but this was actually really hard
because as you probably know a lot of things can go wrong in kubernetes uh so
we were focused on okay let's let's focus on some low hanging fruit and see how we can evolve it uh by adding more
and more error scenarios and more ways that we can help the user right luckily Cube State metric exposes the reasons
that pods terminate or fail to start which was great for us so one Prometheus query later and we had uh a list of all
the things that we were going to tackle uh so on ordered you can see those on the right uh and if we could figure out
okay if I ran into this error and I was helping a user what would I do to debug it and maybe we can automate that uh so
that the user can actually selfs serve uh fixing the the errors so the errors
are uh invalid image name image pull back off crash loop back off error
create container config error item memory and Readiness probe failures Readiness probe failures actually didn't
show up in cuate metric but that was a question we saw a lot so we wanted to fix it too so like I said we were thinking okay
how do we actually debug these errors and uh we had a bit of an epiphany which actually seems really obvious in
hindsight uh which was okay for these errors we can just check the Manifest uh and they have pretty good error messages
in kubernetes and I tell you why they have good error messages which is a
invalid image name image pull back off item memory killed create container config erir usually it's just they have
put the wrong image in they don't have enough memory or they've referenced a secret or config map that doesn't actually exist like I said the error
messages for these are really good so you can actually just show that error message to the user and it's generally
enough uh and we'll have a look at an example in a second these other areas were errors were a little more
interesting uh crash Lo back off error and Readiness probe failure it's because
these errors are the ones that cross the boundary from infrastructure into the application code and as an
infrastructure engineer while you know a lot about the infrastructure you can only get the user so far because you don't actually know what they're doing
in their code or what an exception means you know it means about as much to you as the infrastructure means to ass set
some of them so the idea here was okay maybe we can get the user far enough so
that we can put them back into the context of their service so that they can start thinking about their service again and actually getting value from
the infrastructure instead of fighting against it so we thought crash loop back offl an error and Readiness probe we can
usually show the crash logs right as it crashed and see okay did they print out any stock traces or any useful
information and uh also for readiness probe we wanted to show the kubernetes events because that's where Readiness
probe failures are reported in kubernetes great so what we ended up
with our visual representation was this and so this was our first cut of it and
you can see even if you don't know a lot about kubernetes uh but you know some of the principles around pods that it's

it says two and the other one say one so these are like very uh like lwh hanging
user experience uh principles that we can apply that are very common out there
uh and we can apply into the kubernetes context in order for to teach them a bit about kubernetes and uh lower the
barrier to entry and just so that there's like no confusion about the that
these are errors we also have an aggregated list of all the errors and the pods uh explaining you know this is
the Pod it happened to and this is the exact error and then you see this button on the right hand side that says help and
that was very important for us because that's where we actually show the user uh the next part which is this the
proposed solution so one thing that really annoys me is that when you have
infrastructure tooling that says you have this error and then you say okay what can I do to fix that and it just
Smiles at you it doesn't actually tell you what do I do next uh so the the important thing we
did here was we we analyzed the detected error from kubernetes which was in this case my container has crashed uh it's in
the error State because it's restarted two times and then we explain again what that means but at a different layer we
basically say your container has exited with a nonzero exit code it was two
which becomes very clear to the user okay I think I can tell what happened here and we say you should check the logs to see if there are any stack
traces that tell you what happened and by the way here are the logs you know so we are bringing this straight to the
user without them having to First figure out uh by looking at the uh the Pod
status okay this container crashed and it exited for this reason maybe I should check the logs but I must remember to

ID right so the title of this talk is not here's how I built a kubernetes plat
or demystified our kubernetes platform with backstage so I want to finish up by talking about how you could do the same
and the principles behind the open source PL uh and how we can make it better
together so one of the difficulties with kubernetes platforms and building tools
that cover a lot of different kubernetes platforms is that it's difficult to make
tools that are generic enough for a lot of organizations to use because there's no one kind of standard kubernetes setup
like our kubernetes setup is probably not like your kubernetes setup you might run on a different Cloud you might use a
different I am group uh or a different multi-tenant multi-tenancy
policy uh and so if I just shipped a Spotify kubernetes plugin uh I would
basically be saying if you do everything like us then you can use this and if you don't tough but I didn't want to say
that so we thought about you know what way we would do what way we would form the correct abstractions so that
everyone could use this and it didn't matter what cloud you were on it didn't matter what IR am policy you were
using so this uh diagram is from the original uh kubernetes plugin open
sourcing RFC and backstage you can go look at it in GitHub and look at the conversation and our idea here was um if
we create these three abstractions that answer three important questions we'll be able to support a lot of different
people using the kubernetes plug-in and those abstractions are off provider cluster provider and service locator and
the off provider the question it's asking you is how are you going to authen ithenticate users against this
cluster are you going to use cloud I are you going to use open ID uh are you going to just use a service account and
maybe keep your uh keep the view read only those those are all valid implementations so we decided to just
support them all uh the other question is how are you going to tell backstage
how to discover where those clusters are so you can think of the cluster provider as service Discovery for clusters and
the simplest one is there's a config file and you write you know which clusters you want it to connect to but
it can get uh as complicated as you point it towards a cloud provider API and it just configures
itself and uh finally we got the service locator which is one of the the more interesting ones uh unfortunately this
one is the one that's much more based on your multi-tenancy model and how you use kubernetes inside your organization and
basically what it's asking is which cluster is my service actually running on so I can filter out the ones it's not
running on and not call them uh and the default for this is that it will just call all those clusters uh but there is
a lot of interesting conversation about other implementations that we can add uh
and if you have a multi- tency policy that you think is different from everywhere else this is where you can slot that in and just use the open
source code and have your custom code in your backstage setup
so what are our lessons uh I think our main one is talking to our users uh this is really
critical for us to figure out what are users struggling with because it's easy for us as kubernetes administrators to
say kubernetes is very easy if you want to figure out what's wrong you list all the pods in the name space and you find one that's crashing and you do a
describe and then you run logs or sometimes you run events and that's not really helpful uh so we we uh got a lot
of information for our users saying you this process needs to be simplified because I don't want to have to worry
about the infrastructure I just want to worry about my service and get it working and the other thing is asking for feedback uh like I said my favorite
feature of it was actually the group buy which was not my idea uh but we got that through feedback uh and added it in and
it's been incredibly useful uh you also want to treat your platform tools like a product so you
want to provide support for it like I said you don't want to put it out there and just say good luck uh and you want
to probably be on call for them as well if you do on call uh the other important
lesson here is that we shifted the user's interaction to be service oriented and not infrastructure oriented
so there was no context switching there was no mental map of this service runs on that cluster in this name space those
remain infrastructure issues that we can handle and the users can focus on the service and the last one is around
automating your debugging process and one of the easiest ways to do that is to just think about how you would do it and
simplify it enough that you can just kind of give the answer to the
user so finishing up uh you might ask yourself I actually use the kubernetes plugin this
